summary: This is a 'nolle prosequi' filing from the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, formally recommending the dismissal of the criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein due to his death. The document notes the indictment was filed on July 2, 2019, and Epstein died on or about August 10, 2019, before trial.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (19 Cr. 490) who was charged with conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and sex trafficking of minors. The document states he died on or about August 10, 2019, while the case was pending.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed the document, directing the filing of the nolle prosequi order.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)) who is noted as the one to 'SO ORDER' the recommendation.

events.title: Indictment Filed
events.description: Indictment 19 Cr. 490 was returned, charging Jeffrey Epstein with one count of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and one count of sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died while the criminal case was pending, but prior to any trial or final judgment.

events.title: Filing of Nolle Prosequi Recommendation
events.description: Assistant United States Attorneys filed a recommendation for an order of nolle prosequi (declination to prosecute) due to Epstein's death, leading to the abatement and dismissal of the indictment.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was formally charged on July 2, 2019, with conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and sex trafficking of minors (Case 19 Cr. 490).
Epstein died on or about August 10, 2019, while the criminal case was pending but before trial or final judgment.
The legal principle of 'abatement' applies, meaning the indictment must be dismissed because the defendant died before a final judgment was issued.
The document is a formal prosecutorial recommendation (nolle prosequi) filed by the U.S. Attorney's Office to dismiss the case due to Epstein's death.
The filing was signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman and directed to Judge Richard M. Berman.
